instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
I'm working on a water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. I did a lot of work, cleaning the board and changing this parts:
<CAPACITOR>C5120</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3740</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C2951</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5131</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5490</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5491</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5492</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5482</RESISTOR>, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

I did a reflow for <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>.

The naked board starts with 36mA for half a second, falls down to 9mA and goes up to 16mA after a second. Green light flashes for 2 Seconds and then orange light stable.
After soldering <TRANSISTOR>Q5490</TRANSISTOR> und <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> the board was a bit warm and it took for one start something between 200-300 mA and the ventilator was running. This was only one time.

Here are my measurements:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> = 8,6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> = 8,6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> = 8,6v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> = 19,0v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 19,0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5,0v
   <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0,0V
   <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0,0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3v
   <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0,0v
   <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0,0v
   <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0,02v
   <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0,1v

<SIGNAL>P5VS4_DRVH</SIGNAL> = 0,0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0v

My troubleshooting has now stalled. It would be great if you could help me further.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC (DC) signals.

Original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger?
Did you test with lab PSU, or fake charger too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0.0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.38v

I found these PCH RTC signals - did you mean this? Sorry for stupid asking :-(
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> = 0.4v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL> = 1.4v

I was testing with lab PSU and Magsafe2 cable from a 85W. Also with Original 85W Magsafe2 - same behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
I specified 4 DC signals...

"<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v"
Nothing more appears close to it (in the same PCH block)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
This three are shown together on page 72 in the schematic:
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> = 0.4v
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = (3.3v
These are the only signals with PCH and RTC in the name (searching in FlexBV).

Searching for RTC only, i found this two signals more:
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL> = 1.4v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

Maybe i have a shitty boardview and schematic for this board? Should I look for someone else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
We've talked many times about RTC signals on the forum.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
The mentioned signals go to RTC block; didn't say to have RTC in name!

Just in case, check <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> too.

Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, having all previous signals OK, points to PCH problem.
However, we are still pending about <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
Ok, thanks for the clarification because of the RTC signals. Here are the missing values ...

<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> = 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.2v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 16mA
threads.message:
Possibly accumulated crap underneath PCH.
Try heating it with quality flux.
